awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The effects of changing rainfall patterns on nitrogen cycling and leaching losses in agroecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
Rainfall patterns are currently changing in the midwestern U.S., with an increasing proportion of rain falling in very heavy rain events. This intensification of rainfall patterns may have important consequences for rain-fed agriculture.  In particular, intensification of rainfall may alter the availability and losses of soil nitrogen. Nitrogen is an essential crop nutrient, but it is also very mobile.  Only about half the nitrogen added to soil in fertilizer is taken up by crops, with much of the remainder lost to the environment. Leaching is one of the most important pathways through which nitrogen is lost, with possible negative consequences including groundwater contamination and algae blooms and dead zones in rivers, lakes, and the coastal ocean. This research explores how more intense rainfall patterns may affect nitrogen leaching from Midwestern agricultural ecosystems. The project also seeks to identify management practices which may mitigate enhanced nitrogen leaching in the face of climate change.  

This research will be conducted using an ecosystem-scale rainfall manipulation experiment at the Kellogg Biological Station Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) site in southwest Michigan. Agricultural fields under conventional and no-till management are exposed to ambient rainfall as well as rainfall patterns with extended dry periods and large, simulated rainfall events.  Leaching will be estimated with tension lysimeters to measure soil water nitrogen concentrations, and a model to estimate soil water flux. Deep soil sampling to 1.2m will trace the movement of nitrate down the soil profile over the course of a year and in response to individual rainfall events. The results will be shared with extension specialists, policymakers, and other local stakeholders and will provide opportunities for mentoring undergraduates.

por.por_cntn:
As global surface temperatures rise due to human-induced greenhouse gas emissions, increases in atmospheric moisture and changes in atmospheric circulation are resulting in altered precipitation patterns. The proportion of total precipitation that falls in extreme events is increasing in many places around the world, including the United States (U.S.) Midwest, a globally important region of agricultural production. Agriculture is a major source of reactive nitrogen (N) inputs to the environment, where N can have a range of detrimental consequences. In particular, N leached from agriculture contributes to widespread eutrophication of estuaries and coastal ecosystems, and contamination of groundwater where it poses threats to human health. In this research, we sought to understand how more extreme rainfall patterns affect N leaching from cropping systems in the U.S. Midwest, and how tillage practices moderate the N leaching response of cropping systems to more extreme rainfall patterns. This grant specifically funded work to understanding hydrological and biogeochemical processes in the deep soil profile.

Results of work funded by this grant showed that extreme rainfall patterns increase water flux through the soil profile. This was demonstrated by results of a water tracer experiment, and simulations with a hydrological model. This effect was particularly pronounced in no-till cropping systems, where rapid flow may occur through channels created in the soil by roots and animals, which are destroyed in systems managed with tillage. This type of water flow may effectively “bypass” large volumes of soil.

We also found extreme rainfall patterns increase nitrate leaching in cropping systems managed with tillage, but not in no-till cropping systems. We estimated nitrate leaching by combining water flux estimations from the hydrological model with field measurements of soil water nitrate concentrations. We hypothesize that the difference in the effects of extreme rainfall patterns between cropping systems is due to the presence of the aforementioned channels in soils under no-till management, which allow water flowing through the soil to effectively “bypass” the nitrogen in it.

This research has the potential to help inform both agricultural management and policy by elucidating how climate change may affect crop N availability on farms as well as N losses to the environment. Our preliminary results suggest that no-till management may buffer agricultural soils to N leaching losses; however, more research is needed under a wider range of environmental and agronomic conditions to confirm these results. This work will be disseminated not only to other scientists, but also to extension specialists and other relevant groups. Several undergraduate students were also involved in this research and were mentored by Co-PI Hess.


Last Modified: 06/04/2017
Modified by: Laura Hess
